subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: international quikscript
msgSnippet: When Shakespeare was penning his plays, I believe standardized spelling was a concept that did not exist.  That did not stop publishers from publishing books.
messageBody:
When Shakespeare was penning his plays, I believe standardized spelling was a concept that did not exist.  That did not stop publishers from publishing books.  I understand times have changed since 1600.  Nevertheless, the fact that publishers "want" a standardized spelling has more to do with tradition than necessity I expect.  In the last four centuries, the idea that there is a "standard spelling" is now firmly entrenched, and we have seen the problems that has caused in English.  Once a spelling is "fixed," no one has the authority to change it in the future.  We need to throw out the concept of one correct spelling.  Otherwise, I cannot see how we are to continue to modernize our spelling to keep pace with the changes in pronunciation.

What if publishers edited their authors but did not feel compelled to modify their spelling and accepted that there can be variations from one country to the next or from one major accent  to another major accent?  Obviously, most authors are sending their publishers digital versions of their works these days, rather than typed or penned manuscripts.

Another issue is involves the changes the publishing industry will undergo in the future.  Before long, it may be that books will be printed as the demand calls for them, and the concept of a first printing of a certain number of copies may disappear from the industry altogether.  The next step is already appearing.  My wife recently bought me a Kindle from Amazon.  It downloads books off the web directly into its memory.  There is no printed form per se.  That being the case, when QS is adopted, it would be child's play to print a version in RP or General American or General Indian English and let the software handle the spelling conversions from one accent to another.  An e-book user may be given the choice to pick the accent to have he book delivered in with no more concern wasted on spelling than I waste worrying whether I will be able to understand an Englishman speaking RP.  In other words -- none.

Paige

John Cowan wrote:

pgabhart scripsit:

> I believe you are making a mountain out of a molehill here. It is much
> simpler to simply let people spell words in the manner that seems
> natural to them.

That's fine as long as QS is used only by individuals. But if publishers
adopt it, they will want a standardized spelling, preferably an
international one. It's true that English has never had an academy,but
that doesn't mean we don't have standardized spellings, which are
historically maintained by a feedback loop between publishers and
lexicographers. Dictionaries record the spellings actually used
by publishers, and then publishers adopt those same dictionaries as
authorities for their house spellings.

It's already very annoying to publishers to have to put out multiple
editions of a book in various national spellings: a real break with TO
would immediately lead to calls for a unified spelling for all published
works (which would then be the one taught in schools, etc.). If you
don't want that to be a purely American version, since Americans are
both numerically and politically dominant, then a plan for international
standard QS had better be in place from the start.
